Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Investigation of the Effect of Fly Ash Variability on Cement Paste Microstructure and Mechanical Properties Using Simulated Fly Ash

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research will improve our understanding of the fundamental factors controlling the reactivity of fly ash in Portland cement concrete, leading to more accurate predictive models of performance that will enable the calculation of optimum cement replacement factors for fly ash/cement mix design,. The major innovation is the use of a simulated whole fly ash, which matches all the major properties of a real fly ash, as a model system for investigating systemically the individual factors that control its reactivity. These major properties include the glassy phase composition, the inert mass fraction and composition, and the particle size distribution (PSD). Each simulated fly ash will be a mixture of several types of synthetic glassy particles made with characteristic chemical compositions that match those of real fly ashes. These compositions will be based on analyses of individual fly ash particles using Computer Controlled SEM. The PSD, glass chemical composition and inert fraction will be independently varied among the simulated fly ashes. The mixing of the solid particles will be done using the novel Resonance Acoustic Mixing method to ensure homogenization. This research uses a combination of three measurement techniques to measure the reactivity at different length scales: wet chemistry, thermogravimetry, and standard tests of engineering properties such as compressive strength and durability. Also, the molecular structure of the gel hydration products will be characterized with solid state NMR.

This multiscale approach provides a bridge from individual particle data to macroscopic engineering properties. The results of this research will lead to a model of the reactivity as a function of the glass composition, PSD and inerts fraction. It will accelerate the usage of fly ash as a replacement for Portland cement by the concrete industry. In terms of economic benefits, the increased use of fly ash will lower the cost of concrete structures. The environmental benefits include the reduction in the number of landfills otherwise needed for fly ash disposal, as well as reduced energy consumption and lower CO2 emissions from Portland cement manufacture. This collaborative project will enhance the research and education for undergraduate and graduate students between two institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
SUMMARY

The objective of this research was to apply the simulated fly ash approach to investigate the effect of fly ash variability on the the performance of fly ash/cement mixes. The simulated whole fly ash was prepared to match all the major properties of a real fly ash including the glassy phase composition, inert fraction and composition, and the particle size distribution.

This investigation focused on the effect of variation in the fly ash glass composition while the other major properties were held constant. The chemical composition of several thousand individual particles from a Coal Creek, IA, source fly ash were determined by computer into four clusters having relatively narrow ranges of composition. A set of four synthetic fly ash glasses were prepared based on the mean composition of each cluster. The Reactivity of each glass in simulated pore solution was measured by wet chemistry. The rates of silica dissolution of two of the glasses were measured in pH 12 solutions prepared with either LiOH or Ca(OH)2 .The results showed that both have lower normalized silica dissolution rates in the Ca(OH)2 solution.   

Three simulated whole fly ashes were made by combining varying fractions of Al-Si, Hi-Si and Hi-Ca synthetic fly ash glasses over a range of 10%. The reactivity of these simulated fly ashes in cement paste was measured on both the micro and macro length scales using an array of analytical techniques. On the micro scale, low temperature thermoporosimetry and SEM image analysis have been employed to quantify the changes in pore size distribution (PSD) of the cement pastes over time since the decrease in large-sized pores is a measure of reaction progress. However, no significant difference was observed in the rate of PSD change among the samples. Thermogravimetry (TGA) and X-ray diffraction (XRD) were used to determine the calcium hydroxide consumption which also indirectly indicates the hydration of glass. The result of the three samples are comparable. In addition the early hydration kinetics of these simulated fly ash/cement pastes was measured by isothermal calorimetry. Comparison with calorimetry data of pure cement pastes found no significant difference suggesting that there is no pozzolanic action of glasses within the first 7 days.

The macroscale reactivity measurements consisted of compressive strength tests on 5 cm mortar cubes made with the simulated fly ash/cement mixes. There was no significant difference in the compressive strength development among these samples. This is consistent with the microscale test results.

The overall results suggest that the simulated fly ashes have similar performance at least within the 10% variation range in Al-Si, Hi-Si and Hi-Ca glass fractions investigated in this research. This is because these glasses have such a low silica dissolution rate that they do not form CSH gel to cause any change in microstructure within the experimental time frame.

The reactivity of the fly ash glasses depends in a complex way on the aluminum, calcium and silicon contents of the glass. In some cases the rate of dissolution of Si in the pore water solution is enhanced. In others it is inhibited by the formation of surface layers. Additional research using a wider range of glass chemical compositions is required to fully understand these relationships and hence to develop predictive models of the fly ashes as SCMs.

In the first year, this project provided opportunities for training high school students in the summer and also for a visiting scholar. The students were trained in laboratory safety and quality assurance before they participated in this group research and they were closely monitored. The program for the high school students was for 15 weeks; the program for the visiting scholar was for 12 months. This project also provided an opportunity for training one University of Maryland doctoral student for three years. He was trained on the preparation of synthetic fly ash, simulated fly ash and the use of advanced techniques such as thermoporosimetry, isocalorimetry, XRD, TGA and SEM to characterize samples. A second University of Maryland mater's student was trained in image analysis.

 


Last Modified: 08/05/2016
Modified by: Amde M Amde
